question: Question_01_(c)
sols:
Following the hint, we have

\begin{align*}
 \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{9x^{2}-6x + 8}{-3x^{3}+4} &= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{x^{2}(9 - 6/x + 8/x^2)}{x^{3}(-3 + 4/x^3)} \\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{1}{x}\cdot \frac{9 - \frac6{x} + \frac8{x^2}}{-3 + \frac4{x^3}}   \\
&= \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{1}{x}\cdot \lim_{x \to \infty}\frac{9 - \frac6{x} + \frac8{x^2}}{-3 + \frac4{x^3}}   \\
&= (0)\cdot \left(\frac{9}{-3}\right) = {\color{blue} 0}\end{align*}

Thus the answer is 0. The splitting of the limit of a product into a
product of limits is valid since the product is finite.
hints:
Factor out the largest power of \emph{x} in both the numerator and the
denominator. Simplify and then see if you can take the limit.
